conclusion: Analyze how shadows A, B, C, and D change when the light source moves backwards.
A decorative birdcage casting shadow A.
The shadow of the birdcage base labeled B.
A small lamp or light fixture casting shadow C.
A decorative cross/sword casting shadow D.
Images show the scene from the same angle but with the light source in different positions.
When a light source moves backwards, shadow size increases, position shifts away, and edges become less sharp.
Shadow A is compact and close to the birdcage with a clearly defined shape.
Shadow A becomes larger, moves farther from the birdcage, and appears more diffuse.
Shadow B is distinct, directly beneath the birdcage, appearing as a dark, defined spot.
Shadow B increases in size, merges with shadow A, and moves farther from the object.
Shadow C appears as a compact dark spot, positioned close to the lamp.
Shadow C becomes larger, moves farther from the lamp, and appears blurrier.
Shadow D is smaller, more defined, and positioned closer to the ornate cross.
Shadow D increases in size, the cross shape is more prominent, moves farther from the object, and becomes less sharp.
All shadows increase in size, move farther from objects, and become less defined.
Shadow relationships remain consistent but with increased spacing and size.
Changes follow physical principles of light and shadow as light source moves farther away.
